newsitem.title: INDIA: FEATURE - Calcutta Chinese to celebrate HK handover.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Calcutta Chinese to celebrate HK handover.

text.p: Calcutta's dwindling Chinese community is watching Hong Kong's handover to Beijing with pride -- and mixed feelings about its own place in India.
The Chinese who have dwelt in this eastern Indian city for generations are famous for their restaurants and their hand-crafted shoes.

"Happiness is an expression of the heart. The land (Hong Kong) has come back to us just like Goa came back to India," Hou Wang Lin, secretary of the city's Chinese Cultural and Entertainment Association, told Reuters.
Goa, a tiny coastal state in western India, was "liberated" by Indian troops from Portuguese rule in December 1961.
Hou said he was elated that Hong Kong was returning peacefully to the embrace of the mainland.

"We are going to celebrate on June 30 at 9.30 p.m. (1600 GMT). It will be July 1 in China then," he said, adding that Chinese astrologers were being consulted for an auspicious time for celebrations to begin.
A PROUD MOMENT
"This is a proud moment not only for the Chinese but for all Asian people," said Hou, who owns a popular Chinese restaurant.
Hou is a second-generation Calcuttan whose family had roots in China's southern Guangdong province, which borders Hong Kong. "We are the Hakka people," he said.
The Chinese Association will gather local Chinese for a feast, and its members hope to watch the Hong Kong handover ceremony live on television.
"There will be lots of fireworks, dancing and dinner parties," Hou said.

"It is good that Hong Kong is going back to mainland China and we hope our relatives who live in Hong Kong won't have problems because of the handover," said Chen Kho Qui, 44, a leather tannery owner.
"We are worried about the future of our relatives and friends in Hong Kong after the handover," said Yang Kuo Lien, 57, another tannery owner.
TANNERIES, RESTAURANTS PUT ENCLAVE ON MAP
About 5,000 Chinese live in a small enclave called Tangra, known locally as Chinatown, on Calcutta's outskirts.
Over the past two decades they have transformed what was once a marshy wasteland into a bustling neighbourhood.
The growth of the tanneries and a spurt in Chinese restaurants in the locality were crucial in putting Tangra on the map of India's most populous city.
"This is the best place to have original Chinese food," said Manik Das, one of the many Calcuttans who drive up to Chinatown on the weekends to queue up outside the Lee restaurant.
The narrow winding road cutting across Chinatown is flanked by open drains that emit the stench of raw hides and the odour of chemicals spewed from the nearby leather tanneries.

New Delhi's Outlook newsmagazine said last month that the Chinese, who own 230 of Tangra's 550 tanneries, have also been hit by a recent Supreme Court ruling that ordered them to move to a planned leather complex on the southern outskirts of Calcutta.

Spurred by such instability, the younger Chinese are hurrying towards the exits and Calcutta's Chinese population has dwindled to about 5,000 from more than 20,000 a decade earlier, residents said. BUT YOUNGER CHINESE WANT TO GO WEST
"They want to go abroad because places like Toronto and Taipei are beautiful," said Stephen Lee, 20, a third-generation Calcuttan.
Hou said Chinese living in Calcutta faced many problems and were forced to seek greener pastures in the West.
"I still can't get an Indian passport. They (authorities) say I was born under British rule," he said.
India gained independence from Britain in 1947.
Many young Calcuttan Chinese who travel to overseas universities are attracted by the better quality of life in the West and opt to remain there, Lee said.
Lee's family, which also traces its origin to Guangdong province, runs a restaurant in Chinatown.
"No reaction," said Lee when asked about his feelings on the Hong Kong handover.
"We have become more Indian than Chinese," added Chang Min Lee, editor of Overseas Chinese Commerce of India, the community's ailing morning newspaper. "What can I say about the handover?"
